reviewText: With the creation of a "new animal" using three humans unwillingly attached together, complete with sickening blood and gore shown in close-up images, horrifying screams of terror, and a maniacal scientist who will stop at nothing to make his experiment successful, the Human Centipede is truly a modern day B-movie. It resembles the cheap, campy monster flicks of the fifties; the ones that usually featured awful acting and effects and low budgets. But these films were still were enjoyable for what they were. After all, it's hard to hate a movie about a giant blob ready to swallow an entire town, or giant mutated insects arriving on earth to cause chaos. The same goes for the Human Centipede.I originally thought I was going to despise this film before viewing it, considering the terrible track record horror films have had of late. When horror is in this bad of a state, what chance does a movie about a mad scientist making three humans into a giant centipede have? On the contrary, the movie is fairly well made and features more surprises and scares than you would expect. It also features characters that are 100% racially/sexually stereotyped and repulsion to the extreme (Given, the target audience won't mind either).It starts with the mad doctor, played by Dieter Laser (who attempts a modern day Nazi-like menace with all his will), taking out his first victim for the experiment with a tranquilizer. Then we meet the two teenage girls in the film, Ashley and Lindsey, at a hotel about to visit a friend. They get in their car and set off to their destination. On the way their car breaks down on a road next to the woods and they spend a while searching for a ride until they decide to look for a house to get help at in the woods. Big mistake.The plot of the film, a mad doctor making a new "animal" out of three people, has a scientific background to it. By cutting off the three victims kneecaps and making them stick at a 90 degree angle, and then cutting their anuses and attaching the other victims' mouths to an anus so waste can come out of the anuses and into the mouths until it leaves the third human, the three are joined together as a centipede. For some the thought that someone had to think of this is bad enough. And for all means and purposes, the Human Centipede may very well be the sickest movie ever made.But here it's not the amount of pain and torture in question here, it's the imagination that went into it. Director Tom Six has put a horrible but unique concept into a Hollywood film, much more interesting than just seeing razors or knives going into someone's skin. Heck, this movie surpasses any of the Saw movies' torture schemes.

reviewText: I finally watched THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE BLU-RAY (I found it on sale at another store so I couldn't resist) and I have to say that for an independent film it was pretty good. Film and lighting techniques are professional looking, there are no jump cuts, the special effects look realistic (including hair and makeup) and the the actors are really top notch (especially Dieter Laser who plays the mad German doctor). This film could have easily become really campy but it never tips into that area and stays in the realm of the macabre.For those that don't know about this movie it's about a German doctor who was a well known in his field for successfully separating Siamese (conjoined) twins, but somewhere along the lines Dr. Heiter (Dieter Laser) goes insane and wants to create a conjoined human aka the "human centipede." He does so successfully with dogs, but then turns his crazed obsession to finding the right human guinea pigs and he does so with three victims (Ashley C. Williams, Ashlyn Yennie, Akihiro Kitamura) who turn out to be the perfect biological match.Anyway, the film is pretty perverse and kind of gruesome, but you don't really see explicit stuff (i.e. when the three people are attached you'll see the scar and stitches but everything else is obscured by bandages) so it's more psychological because your mind is filling in the blanks.I did find some points in the movie that stretched the suspension of disbelief, not so much with the actual human centipede, but why a character would do this or that. Otherwise the film is pretty good. The BLU-RAY picture quality is sharp and vivid with bright colors and black, blacks.THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE isn't for everyone. But for an indie movie that cost 1,500,000-Euros (according to IMDb) to make and a somewhat gross thriller that has introduced something unique to the horror genre it isn't so bad. reviewText: It would be easy to dismiss The Human Centipede as unworthy of much note.  But it's too well done on some levels.  The cinematography, sound, overall production values and acting by Dieter Laser as the mad doctor are quite good.  If Tom Six and team intended to pursue the familiar route toward mainstream movies by proving their value through a low budget horror flick, they've succeeded.But beneath that slick veneer is a dry husk of a turd.  Unless you're particularly sensitive, new to gore flicks or just not a fan of the genre, sure, you might find this movie disturbing.  But for fans of the genre it's not particularly impressive.  The gore is minimal, mostly suggested through the obviously grotesque notion of making conjoined triplets through the worst imaginable connection of orifices.  There's lots of moaning and crying.  But you never actually see what is suggested by the premise.  That would have required a special effects budget, which this movie clearly didn't have.  Instead, you get diaper service.It's not gory enough to secure a niche in that disreputable genre.  It lacks notable special effects.  It lacks the knowing sense of dark humor that made movies like "Re-Animator" and "Saw" classics.  And it lacks the out of control sense of insanity that made the original "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" so disturbing even after several viewings.Oddly enough, there are tiny gems inside that turd.  The head of the human centipede - apparently suddenly possessed by the spirit of Dae-su Oh from "Oldboy" - experiences an eloquent moment of existential crisis, albeit in Japanese which none of the other characters can understand.  This brief moment of nihilistic irony is almost enough to redeem the rest of the movie.  And the two female segments of the centipede mime a persuasive sense of emotional bonding, beyond the physical, although the director neglects to develop it, or perhaps chooses to minimize it, so that the viewer never quite feels much more than a bit of detached pity.But it's still only a couple of tiny gems wrapped in a giant turd covered in glittery wrapping.  Not really worth getting your hands dirty.

reviewText: There are two kinds of horror movies nowadays; gorefest flicks that go right for the throat and give you a healthy dose of blood and guts, and more psychological horror films that leave a lasting impression and prove that what is implied is sometimes more shocking than what is shown. "The Human Centipede" falls somewhere in the middle, delivering some enough viscera to appease the splatter fans while providing a truly horrifying premise to really make you squirm in your seat. It's not a great film by any stretch, but it offers a level of originality that is not often seen in horror films today. Part horror, part twisted fetish movie, this is unlikely to be a movie you'll forget anytime soon.The center of the movie is Dr. Heiter,a reclusive former doctor who was once a respected surgeon who specialized in the separation of Siamese twins but now devotes his time to his obsession - combining animal to make one cohesive body. As luck would have it, two American tourists happen upon his house one rainy night and he decides to keep them for his experiment. Add in a Japanese tourist he kidnaps and he's ready to unveil his masterplan: to create a human centipede. How he achieves this is really the most horrifying aspect of the movie; he plans for them to all share one digestive tract, with the person in the front eating, passing waste through the middle person and finally out the end of the back person. This requires two of the people to be surgically grafted, rectum to mouth, and their knee ligaments are severed so that the cannot stand up. The bulk of the movie is the surgical procedure, with the rest being devoted to the mad doctor "training" his human centipede and their hopes to escape.As horror movies go, this is one of the more interesting ones that works on some levels and doesn't on others. The production is above average for it's type, especially considering that oddities like this are typically low-budget European or Asian exploitation or Arthouse films, so it obviously has a bigger budget than most. The acting by the three "pieces" of the centipede is patchy at best, especially the Japanese male who has been given some incredibly bad dialogue and who spends the bulk of the movie screaming and shouting nonsensical banter. The best performance of the movie comes from German stage actor Dieter Laser, who plays an effectively creepy villain akin to a more unhinged Hannibal Lecter. He is an imposing presence and his facial expressions and manner of speaking really add to the level of discomfort the movie gives off. While the graphic violence is enough to make you cringe at times, the real horror comes from the scenario that the three victims find themselves in. The mad doctor explains to them, in detail, what he is going to do, and then he does it. Trying to imagine yourself in such an ordeal is really where this film hits the mark, and it will definitely leave an impression on you long after you've seen the film.For all it's strengths and faults, I enjoyed "The Human Centipede" and I can see it becoming a cult classic 10 years from now. With a sequel being made already, it is likely to have a good following among fans and draw the ire of film critics and parents for years to come. The originality of the plot and the shock value are enough to make this an easy recommendation for horror fans who are looking for something a little different.
summary: A watchable horror oddity and future cult classic

reviewText: Here's a film to bring people together--literally.  Director Tom Six came up with the concept of this sick story from a joke made with friends.  This joke was aimed at child molesters, suggesting as punishment they should have their mouths surgically sewn "to the (rear end) of fat truck drivers".  When Mr. Six pitched this idea to potential investors, he omitted this central aspect of the plot.  The rest is underground horror history.The Human Centipede starts off irritatingly derivative.  A couple of beautiful ladies from New York are touring through Europe.  Sheesh, didn't you two gals watch HOSTEL or TAKEN?  This is obviously a bad idea.  They get invited to a party, have a tire blowout in the middle of bfe, and of course have no cell phone reception.  I know, that setup has been beaten to death.  But new levels of inconceivable evil are about to be woven in.For me, the most unnerving part of this film was the main scoundrel himself, the wicked Dr. Heiter (Dieter Laser).  He just looks superbly creepy as all hell.  Plus his detatched, cold persona will send shivers down your spine.This acclaimed doctor had received recognition from his brilliant skill in seperating conjoined twins.  Now his next effed up surgical plan is quite the opposite.  He dreams of making new creatures that share a single digestive system.  Sick!  The portions of one meal go through three different people.  I can't think of a more humiliating, degrading, just flat out awful predicament.This film does surprisingly show some restraint in unleashing this atrocity upon the viewer.  It contains relatively little blood or nudity.  We're left to witness the extreme awkwardness of the victims as they cope with the hopelessness of their situation.  Plus we are subjected to the whims of a deranged madman, as he does the unthinkable.Overall, this is a film I would mildly recommend to fans of hardcore horror only.  It is well made and acted for the most part.  It's definitely not something you see everyday, thank goodness.  Proceed with caution.Sharing isn't always caring.

reviewText: In an interview, Tom Six, the director of The Human Centipede, said that his movie explores the nature of humanity. Dr. Heiter, a renown surgeon, known for his ability to separate conjoined twins, has no true understanding of humanity and the bonds that bring us together. He dreams of having such knowledge, but in his twisted mind, such bonds come from forced interaction, a forced need to cooperate. Thus, he creates the human centipede, attaching three young victims, head to tail, so that they crawl about on their knees, unable to do anything without cooperating.And they do, but not in the way Dr. Heiter expected. They learn to fight back, to escape, like Frankenstein's monster taking revenge on the real monster, the one who created him. But they do this because they are human, not because they are learning to be human. They feel each other's fear and pain, they hold one another up, they forgive one another what they cannot control.Yet, did Six have to make his points (and there are many in this deeply layered film) in such a degrading way, making us feel like depraved voyeurs to want to see these three people survive and wreak havoc? There are times when he seems to be indicting the audience as much as Dr. Heiter. I'm still not sure if this film is gratuitous, or highly effective or both. reviewText: In what context is "The Human Centipede (First Sequence)" necessary? Some movies are made with the intention of sending a message, while others are made purely for entertainment; the more I try to figure out which category this movie falls into, the more confused I get, for it doesn't seem to belong to either one. What message could it possibly be sending? That suffering is even more unpleasant than death? Thanks, but I already got that from "Downloading Nancy." In what way is it entertaining? Because the filmmakers have found an entirely new way to shock and disgust the audience? Just because I've never seen anything like it before doesn't mean I'm going to enjoy looking at it. It also doesn't mean that it should ever have been shown in the first place.This movie fails on a level even more basic than those of setting, character, pacing, and visual appeal - that of the underlying concept, which is so spectacularly bad that nothing the actors did or said could have saved it. It's not something I wish to describe. I will say that the director consulted a surgeon to ensure that the concept was "100% medically accurate," a measure that proves just how out of touch he is with today's horror community. Absolutely no one will care how medically accurate it is. All that matters is, is it scary? Yes, but not in the way you're thinking; it scared me to think that this could be the next frontier in horror filmmaking, that audiences may someday only delight in content so sickening that it transcends campy fun and becomes an endurance test.It opens with two characters who are not characters at all, but merely expendable female victims with no discernable personalities and no sense of depth. Their names are Lindsay and Jenny (Ashley C. Williams and Ashlynn Yennie), American tourists vacationing in Germany. In a cinematic twist of fate that even thirty years ago wasn't original, they get lost in the woods on the way to a nightclub and subsequently get a flat tire. Naturally, there's no cell phone service in the middle of nowhere, so they're forced to wander through the woods until they find someone who can help. Lo and behold, there's a house off in the distance. They knock on the door just as it starts to pour rain. The door opens, revealing the wizened Dr. Heiter (Dieter Laser), whose creepy, piercing stare and low, harsh voice should have been enough of an indication for the girls run away.Lindsay and Jenny are invited in. Heiter, who just happens to speak fluent English, offers them each a glass of water, which they accept. They drink up, unaware of the fact that their waters have been spiked with the date rape drug. Are they really so clueless that they forgot the cardinal rule of not accepting a drink from a stranger? Of course they are - they're bound by an unfortunate convention of horror movies, namely that female characters automatically must be nave and helpless. When they awaken, they find themselves strapped to stretchers in Heiter's basement/laboratory/operating room. In due time, they're joined by a kidnapped Japanese tourist (Akihiro Kitamura), who throughout the film does little more than scream obscenities in his native language.What does Heiter want these three for? Does the film's title not tell you everything you need to know? The surgical procedure required to make this possible is described in excruciating detail, although I'm not sure why since I don't think anyone would be interested in the process so much as the results. And what of the results? Let's just say they give a new meaning to the word "excessive," not only in terms of physical appearance, but also in terms of how Heiter forces them to behave once the procedure is done. This isn't horror so much as an exercise in depravity. By the time it was all over, I felt empty inside, not only because of an ending in which absolutely no one wins, but also because I had been denied of anything that could be considered entertaining.This movie has to be seen to be believed, which is not something I recommend you try. The more I think about "The Human Centipede (First Sequence)," the more amazing it seems that it was made, and before that written, and before that conceived of. It's not bad in any usual way; it achieves an entirely new level of badness, one so unpleasant and extreme that it might actually be worth seeing, not because it's any good, but simply because you may never see anything like it again. I take that back - writer/director Tom Six is already at work on "The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence)," which he promises will "go full force in graphic details, making part I look like my little pony." Now I really am scared.

reviewText: This is an incredible horror film, and it is worth remembering that the main character is mad and therefore deep down he is stupid. Two teenage girls staying in a nice Hotel in a nice area of Germany decide to spend an evening out at the Bunker nightclub. On the way they get lost and break down and are accosted by a throwout from the local bier keller who pulls up in his Beetle. The girls would rather stick pins through their eyes or wear flat shoes than let Herr Lowenbrau change one of their hire car tyres, so he gets the message quite quickly and drives off. The girls try to phone the hire company but can't get a service, so they decide to walk across woodland to where they think there might be houses. However the terrain is far too rough for their high heels and, as they don't fancy doing a Camille Keaton at this stage, they whinge back towards the highway where Herr Lowenbrau's pram lights can clearly be seen. Herr Doktor proceeds to point out that he doesn't really like humans but that he is very partial to centipedes. He addresses one as 'my sweet centipede' and also trains a centipede to fetch things. A very clever Medic indeed, and one with an increasingly high opinion of himself,as can be gleaned by his state of the art indoor swimming pool. The girls have tremendous bodies and acting talent but, because of what happens in the storytelling of this film, it can never have the exotic/erotic impact of a really good Giallo. Human Centipede will appeal to anyone who likes good horror, and also probably to those who haven't really tried horror before, since it would be an excellent starting point. It is certainly not ugly nor dirty, and the violence is just what you would expect from a rippingly good horror film. As a guide I would say that the violence is less extreme than the 4 French-directed films Hills Have Eyes, Martyrs, Inside and High Tension. IFC have made a superb unrated Director's cut Bluray print. 16/9. One of the best films not only of 2010 but of any year.

Hitchcock did the same with Psycho, you never see the knife going into the body. But you swear later that it did. Human Centepede is no Hitchcock classic but it does a lot with a low budget and unknown actors. reviewText: "The Human Centipede" could easily have been a schlocky piece of horror trash, but the writer/director team (husband/wife I think?) manage to create something smart and original out of familiar horror elements.In the beginning of the film, the audience is treated to a barrage of very familiar horror movie cliches ... two pretty young girls going out to party, alone in a foreign country, their car breaks down, and, looking for help, end up knocking on the door of (who else?) a mad scientist.And so the horror (and fun) begins. Part of the credit for the film's success goes to Dieter Laser, for playing his sadistic surgeon character as understatedly deranged, which makes him much scarier than if the actor had gone for scenary-chewing histrionics. His character is less motivated by delusions of grandeur than he is just a sadistic overgrown child acting out a bizarre experiment: turning our two heroines, along with another kidnapped Asian tourist, into the titular human centipede.Is the film critiquing modern society's obsession with body modification? Or the scientific community's morals in regards to experimentation? Or recent horror cinema's "torture porn" trend? Possibly. But more than anything, I think the filmmakers created an outrageous concept and challenged themselves to suspend the audience's disbelief enough to make the whole thing seem believable. They succeeded, and it sure is sick, twisted, and kind of fun.

reviewText: Okay, what did you all expect?  This movie's premise is gross beyond human imagination (although apparently not for the writer!). I am a horror fan, not so much a gross out fan, but I do like to be scared.  And I was scared as hell for these people!!Is it a well made movie?  No.  The dialogue was cliche and the plot holes are too numerous to mention.  You can even see a reflection of the film crew in one scene. But if you want to feel your heart pound for 3 poor SOB's who got tagged by the WRONG doctor- sit down and feel your blood pressure rise.It's no masterpiece- but you gotta give it an "A" for originality!

reviewText: There are a few movies and directors that I don't normally lay fandom to in everyday life. It is not only due to the fact that 80% of the population would scratch their head and ask "what?" or "who?" I get that alot with most of the things I do.It has more to do with the fear that these people may actually know these movies and directors, and find them to be, for lack of a better word, "gross" rather than the adjectives I use, such as "raw", "inspiring", "provocative", "so disturbing that you can't look away". Usually, at least two of those adjectives have to be used by me to describe a movie that I like.Some of these movies and directors that have found their way into my heart, or at least, psyche:Meet the FeeblesLeaving Las VegasIrreversibleTakashi MiikeLloyd KaufmanJohn WatersWhen I heard the bar-top reviews of The Human Centipede, the words "gross", "disgusting", "wow, was that vile" came into the explanation time and again, so it seemed that the movie may find itself into the list above. Unfortunately, it fell short.Written and directed by flying Dutchman Tom Six, the plot revolves around a German doctor that had once specialized in separating conjoined twins. After possibly injesting too much acid, the doctor decided to start conjoining people anus-to-mouth to create a human centipede. Two female American tourists and one Japanese guy become the candidates for his experiment. A few people die. And the human centipede? It becomes reality.The acting is fairly well done after the women stop getting lost in the woods. The japanese guy seems to have been taken straight out of a Takashi Miike movie himself. The mad Dr. Heiter probably suffers from OCD and portrays a medical fiend that hates people, as he stated, quite well. There isn't a whole lot of action: one normal chase scene through the house, one gimpy chase scene in the house, a little gunfire, death by injection, death by self-inflicted throat slashing, and a little blood poisoning. Be warned: when people call this movie gross, it is not because it is a gore-soaked horror movie. No, the gross-out has to do with the construction of the human centipede: ass-to-mouth. What do you think will happen when someone on the front end has to do #2?Exactly.However, this is not what makes the movie a little unwatchable until the final 10 minutes. Like so many good directors listed at the beginning of this review, the substance of a movie is both visual and symbolic. The Human Centipede does have its moments of realization for the characters. The Japanese guy has an amazingly subtitled monologue on humanity. When police officers find the human centipede, their disgust shows just how much the 3 characters lost their identity, and humanity, by being merged together. You can only imagine what they would try to charge Dr. Heiter with.The problem is, these deep theme devices don't evolve until the last 10 minutes. Locking the human centipede in a cage, teaching it to play fetch, these were failed attempts because they just seemed comical, because it was obvious what the director was trying to do. The detective's reaction to seeing the human centipede, however, was amazing. The best 10 seconds of the movie. Unfortunately, that's way to short to give this movie a pass in the grading department.Apparently, Tom Six is working on a sequel, The Human Centipede(Final Sequence). Should be interesting to see if he goes high-brow, or even more vulgar.I give this movie 2.5 out of 5 pieces of the human centipede.
summary: Tongue in Cheek, or as the Characters Learn...

reviewText: Director Tom Six claims that he wants to push the limits and make films which are new and different, but what has he really accomplished with HUMAN CENTIPEDE?  Forget the nasty title monstrosity, and what do you have?  Just one more trite, not-very-varied variation of the mad scientist theme which was already overworked by the 1940s.  His film differs from those only in the lack of a happy ending - and even that difference is a predictable cliche of modern film-making.  I suspect that Six fancies himself an artist, but where is the artistry here?  Where are the plot twists? the innovative camera work? the pointed message?  Even the title creature is not very original.  Pulp magazines of the 30s and 40s are full of mad-scientist creations dimly described as unspeakable, disgusting, and obscene: those adjectives allow for such creatures as the human centipede.  Six is merely explicit and nasty.  HUMAN CENTIPEDE is a cruel, apparently woman-and-Oriental-hating piece of sensational garbage aimed at a stupidly sadistic, unimaginative, and  depraved audience - the modern version of the spectators at the Roman gladitorial games. 100% medically accurate?  Of course - but only if one allows that such a creation would die in a very few days of bacterial infection and/or starvation for numbers two and three. Nevertheless, the film bristles with inaccuracies, such as serious wounds that don't bleed much and loud screams from people who should be able to produce only muffled, choking noises. And the announced sequel?  The same thing, only bigger and nastier.  So what is Six's contribution to the genre.  Just this - "mouth-to-anus."  Six depicts numbers two and three swallowing crap - and he expects his audience to do the same.  Shocking?  Not really - just ugly.  And not even original since Six claims SALO as one of his favorite movies. (That is almost all one needs to know about Six.) In fact, to our desensitized audience, the most shocking scene is that one early in the film where the girls' cellphone fails in time of need- OMG! OMG!  Ultimately the most shocking thing about the film is its popularity and its depiction on tee-shirts, birthday cakes, etc.  We have become monsters far worse than anything Tom Six could imagine.

reviewText: For those who know me I seen my share of films and I have seen a lot them, but never before have I seen a film completely missing a script. Even though I've seen this film over a year ago, this film wasn't so bad if you know what kind of film it is. I don't know to me it seems like director Tom Six came up with the idea and then told the actors to make it up as they went for the most part. The reason why I say this is because most of the dialog is made up by "stop" and "please - first in English, then in Japanese - and I'm not sure switching languages is enough of a variation to qualify for a script. The Human Centipede has less of a plot than a music video.  The acting is a mixed bowl of good, decent and bad, but as this is a horror flick, great acting is not something you'd expect anyway. To be honest, I wasn't caught up in the whole gore/sickness of the subject matter but by Dieter's conviction in his role. It's the spookiest thing about this film. The man went for it and he did it well. Andreus Leopuld and Peter Blankenstein both perform their parts well as the 'on the case' detectives. Now as for Ashley Williams and Ashlynn Yennie they were both given totally unrealistic lines, but no one watches these movies to see great acting. The pet was just that. I became less concerned about the creation and more about the Doctor's safety and whether he'd get away with it.The locations are actually pretty great and the special effects are pretty good. Lots of well thought out camera angles and lighting; careful use of prosthetics. But in the end, it doesn't matter what concept you have, what actors you have or how great of a house you've found for your shoot. If your film doesn't have a script, it's probably not a film worth making. With that being said, this film is a must for the collection of any gutter cinema aficionado. No doubt about that. It is not a keeper for repeat viewing, but it is a nice thing to pull out for the visitors who boast they've seen it all.
summary: 2.5...Tom Six really gave no thought on writing this film

reviewText: To even think that Tom Six, the Director, meant this as just another Horror Movie is a total mistake on the viewer's part.  Without going into an in depth interpretation of this movie, I found it to be Black Comedy and totally "Over the Top". Dieter Laser as Dr. Heidel is perfect for the role.  C'mon, you cannot take this movie seriously.  When Dr. Heidel introduces himself to his subjects, he states "I am Dr. Joseph (winks at the girls) Heidel" which is obviously dark humor and then he goes on to explain how he will join individuals A, B, & C together to form his 2nd creation--his 1st being 3 Rottweiler pets of his which didn't make it as a doggy centipede.  His seriousness is truly farcical as the Director meant it to be.  Nobody can truly take this in earnest.I have been watching Horror Movies all of my life and believe "Human Centipede" will become a cult classic.  You have to view this movie as comedy (granted some parts are gross) or what did you expect in the first place considering the Title?  My good friend and I get a kick out of Dr. Heidel's insanity and consider this film having "break through" written all over it.  When I first saw Romero's "Night of the Living Dead", I was totally disgusted at what the movie showed in graphic detail--this is now a big time cult classic as is "The Evil Dead" which was also "way out there" at the time of its release.When the good Dr. Heidel is trying to get his "creation", led by the Japanese dude, to fetch him the paper, it is meant as dark humor. Dr. Heidel is totally insane ("I hate human beings") and should be viewed as an exercise in total madness. Please watch this movie as it was intended: total dark comedy with a human cenepede that only speaks Japanese thrown in for good measure. Even the Trailer/Advertisement & DVD for this flick state: "100% Medically Accurate" and people can actually take this statement seriously? C'mon, this is great stuff!  Excellent movie with a totally maniacal and often hysterical story. Not recommended for anyone without a genuine and somewhat warped sense of humor.  "Fido, comin sie hier!"

reviewText: Love it or hate it--one thing for sure--you'll definitely have a strong opinion about one of the more original entries into the realm of horror we've seen in some time. "The Human Centipede" is an undeniably bent piece of filmmaking! If the very idea of what happens in "The Human Centipede" does not peak your interest, then this is absolutely not the film for you. The long and short of the film's plot involves a mad scientist's experiments to join various creatures into a sequence connected by one long shared digestive system. There's a cruder way of saying that--but we all know what's going on here, so I'll maintain some decorum. After having worked with dogs, he's now ready for a human trial. I just want to say that I was so into the premise of this film. I do not shy away from depravity, and I was one of those sick souls who was rooting for "The Human Centipede" to be the next great thing in avant garde horror.But delightfully mad premise aside, I must ask myself an important question. Was the film "good" and/or was the film "entertaining." Now, I know that "good" is rather subjective. I did like the awkward presence of Dieter Laser as the mad genius. I know some who will proclaim this a brilliant performance, but I'll just say that I found his creepiness unsettling and his moments of overacting lively. The other cast member performances, however, were decidedly uninspired. Two American girls and a Japanese guy form the links of the Centipede--and in an amusing choice, the annoying Americans are placed in positions two and three so we don't have to listen to them speak for the second half of the picture. The Japanese man, now communicating to no one but the audience via subtitles, is so patently absurd--the dialogue isn't remotely believable, it's painfully clunky. When the cops start investigating, the screenplay doesn't improve in quality."The Human Centipede" is so empty headed about police procedure and has no believable protagonists--so when the curiosity wears off, what are we left with? Is the film "entertaining?" The film starts out with promise (despite the performances and dialogue) and the set-up is efficient. Once, however, the centipede is created--the film loses some momentum. I will say that the effects are genuinely good and the film doesn't shy away from what it promises. There is just little to do once the action has taken place. Things become surprisingly one-note and the vision of the centerpiece centipede can't sustain interest for the remainder of the picture. I suppose, in a better film, this might have been a riveting psychological sequence as the victims succumb to their new indignities. But "The Human Centipede" lets things take a more expected course with the police investigation.Great idea! Great visual execution! Clunky Filmmaking! Awful dialogue and performances (although Laser's mania is, at least, interesting)! "The Human Centipede" is a divisive film that some will love and most will hate. Speaking as someone who wanted to love it--I, ultimately, just didn't feel entertained by it. KGHarris, 10/10.
summary: A Terrifically Gruesome Premise That Soars Briefly But Has Nowhere To Fly (Or Crawl)

reviewText: As a true fan of horror this movie is outstanding. I wasn't expecting so much from reading and seeing all the 3star reviews. If you watched this movie thinking it was some horror/kinky type of sexual movie you've been mistaken. The theme of this movie is dehumanizing a person to the point where who they are doesn't even matter. They are just another creation of an Evil Doctor.This film has an outstanding atmosphere to it. The crazy Doctor really brought the movie home. With the wrong cast this could of went bad in a lot of ways but what you get instead is a pretty heavy film with a good story line and memorable roles(The Dr.). Although the Centipede itself wasn't that shocking to look at, it's the idea behind it. Being captured by a lunatic Surgeon and being used in his experiment. It's the age old midnight horror tale but it's been beautifully revived in this film.You don't see many "Monster Creation" movies anymore. When you do they are over the top and cheesy. The Human Centipede brings a realistic monster to the table. Something that isn't so far fetched as a body made from corpses brought back to life.I rate this movie a 5 starer for being unique and brilliant. Bringing an old idea into a new age.

reviewText: The Human Centipede (First Sequence) (Tom Six, 2010)Every once in a while someone attempts to make the grossest movie ever. And oddly, some of these find their way to a major-label release and actually get shown in a theater or two. (Or two thousand, if you're Eli Roth.) Invariably, these "grossest movies ever" pale in comparison to the reigning kings of disgust, T. F. Mous' Men Behind the Sun (the original; you can safely ignore the idiotic sequels) and Hideshi Hino's Flower of Flesh and Blood. (The only movie that's come close in the interim, for me, has been Hisayasu Sato's 1995 flick Naked Blood, but I'm the first to admit the gross-out there is more targeted, and I seem to be among those who find the acts it depicts far more unsettling than most.) But it's always amusing to watch the attempt, no matter how far short it falls on that particular scale. Tom Six, whose Gay in Amsterdam made a few waves back in the middle of the last decade, has thrown his hat in the grossest-movie-ever ring with The Human Centipede (First Sequence), which I was "lucky" enough to catch on the big screen last weekend. For once, Cleveland was a selected city. I got to feel like a big cosmopolitan critic for an hour and a half. (I hope I'm more Ben Mankiewicz than A. O. Scott.) Roger Ebert has lent some cache to the grossest-movie-ever idea in his review ("No horror film I've seen inflicts more terrible things on its victims...", he writes). Far be it from me to second-guess Roger Ebert, but I would postulate that this, like Naked Blood, is another of those vertical-market gross-out pictures where how you feel about the disgust factor will be directly influenced by how you feel about Six's particular gross-out.The film kicks off with Lindsay (Ashley C. Williams in her first screen role since Willow, filmed when she was three years old) and Jenny (Fetch's Ashlynn Yennie) in a hotel room in Germany getting ready for a night of clubbing. Following this scene (and including it, depending on how strict you're willing to be with convention) comes a painful, and yet very funny, string of horror film cliches. I read a recent review of Ax 'em (considered by many to be the worst horror movie ever made) which described it as an endless series of bad horror movie cliches strung together; I thought of that again and again while watching the first half-hour of this movie, but Six does lighten the load with humorous punches. Eventually, the two girls end up at the house of Dr. Heiter (Fuhrer Ex's Dieter Laser, looking very Christopher Walken-ish), a retired surgeon who specialized in the separation of conjoined twins. Of course, the doctor is crazy as a brickhouse rat, and has recently turned his attention to the opposite, conjoining previously separate animals (in an opening-scene prologue, we see Heiter sitting in a car staring at pictures of his first experiment before going off to abduct a trucker). He's decided it's time to try some experiments on humans, and these two lovely, though exceptionally annoying, women come stumbling into his house. Providence! Now all he needs is a third...Okay, about the gross-out factor. It's a one-trick pony, and while I'm sure if you're even mildly interested in the film you already know what it is, I'm not going to spoil it for you. But aside from a few surprisingly sterile scenes of surgery and a bit of blood here and there, the gross-out is all in your head. (At one point I actually found myself looking at it from an academic standpoint, thanks no doubt to the movie's "100% medically accurate!" tagline, and thinking that the doctor could have... no, that would be cheating.)Given that, if the gross-out factor doesn't work for you, the movie falls flat. There were a number of things Six could have done to change that, most notably keeping the humor level as high throughout as it was in the opening scenes. There are a few attempts at humor as time goes on (Heiter teaching the centipede to walk, a couple of run-ins with an overzealous pair of local cops), but Six doesn't seem as if he was going for horror-comedy along the lines of, say, Cabin Fever here, and that turns out to have not been a good idea. Also, Laser is the only real actor in this cast, and while he's good enough to instinctively grasp that he needs to camp it up in order to play with the amateurs, he's not good enough to carry the entire film on his own.All of these problems I could have overlooked had the movie had a strong enough script. And there's the skeleton of a good, maybe even great, script somewhere in this movie. Six's hook is undeniably compelling, whether you end up liking it or not, but once he actually gets where he's going with the creation of the centipede, his idea fountain seems to have petered out. That's when the necessity of the gross-out takes over. Solid gross-out, with nothing else to back it up, can work on occasion, but it has to really be the grossest movie ever (I keep coming back to Flower of Flesh and Blood, which is entirely plotless, but still compelling, in a way that makes you feel like the sickest sonofabitch who ever walked the planet for not being able to tear your eyes away). Otherwise, you really do need a plot. And that road's been travelled, as well (and we're back to Men Behind the Sun). The gold standards, once again, remain the gold standards.Ebert, who gave the film no stars (something he very, very rarely does), did say in the film's defense that Six has "the soul of a dark artist." I'm more inclined to award that accolade to cinematographer Goof de Koning, Six's longtime associate, who knows how to pretty things up in just the right way, and is equally at home in almost-blinding sunlight and the cold operating room, but I do have to admit the silly thing looks good, even if it is mostly style with little substance. There is a sequel in the works; I hope Six comes up with a decent script for it. **

reviewText: Like a rash or a sore that seems relatively harmless at first, Tom Six's "The Human Centipede" does not seem so bad after the viewer bravely steps in front of the screen to watch, in hopes or despite of, what could be the unfolding of the implications of the film's title: two girls and one digestive system, as one critic amusingly puts it. Indeed, aside from some old-fashioned gun shooting sequences, a couple of throat-slitting incidents, and a stabbing through the foot, this is actually one of those films that of which the audience, most likely, is thankful for its relatively minimalistic approach to its subject matter, the title of which already implies that it could be up there alongside some of the grossest and violent films of all time. Ironically, the film is deliberately restraint, and one could even say slow-moving, from those who are merely seeing it from a point of view of a gorehound. But like the aforementioned rash or sore that won't seem to go away, and actually seems to progressively get bigger, "The Human Centipede" still retains that excruciatingly foul and disgusting lingering byproduct from dealing with its premise, regardless of Six's deliberately subtle treatment of it. The idea just oozes with sick abomination and depravity, and no matter how restraint and subtle the director is in approaching it, the foundational base of the idea is just perpetually fraught with vileness a well-meaning, well-intended discourse that will come out of this is still hard to swallow, no pun intended; a self-perpetuating destruction of its credibility if you will, since the idea is pretty sick and nasty to begin with. Still, Six's emphasizing on the three very unlucky victims should be rightly commended: though they start off as typically obnoxious, they are the brunt of some of the most heinous and terrifying treatment in the hands of the evil doctor, played with much gusto by the German actor, Dieter Laser. The ending is brutal, and uncompromising, and the poetry that comes out of the Japanese guy, who finally decides to make a turnaround in response to the situation that he is in is genuinely moving and powerful.Six's "The Human Centipede" is the stuff of really off-putting and foul material, but as his lenses focus on the humiliation, suffering and subjugation of the three victims, as opposed to the doctor's autopsy, or even a prolonged feeding scene of the three characters as the centipede, what could be juvenile, unjustifiable trash is really a work of a director with an unflinching, if not unique, vision. Give credit where credit is due. Having said that, this film is really only for fans of dark, brutal cinema; others beware.

reviewText: Human Centipede. It's been all the rage all over the internet, and for some reason unbeknown to me, even people who don't follow horror movies know about it. For a film that only has a small release that's pretty impressive, so that should already tell you there's something special about it.If you don't know what Human Centipede is all about though, then let me give you a quick one line synopsis...It's a movie about a INSANE doctor who wants to make a "centipede" by sewing people together into a human conga-line of sorts. How is this possible you ask? Lets find out.Lindsay (Ashley C Williams) and Jenny (Ashlynn Yennie) are two attractive girls visiting Germany from New York who decide to have a nice fun-filled night out on the town. While on the road, their car gets a flat tire out in the woods (doesn't that just ALWAYS seem to happen), and after an older gentleman pulls up to help them and hit on them, they decide that maybe walking through the woods to find help is a better plan. Eventually they reach the house of Doctor Heiter (Dieter Laser), a man who from the moment you see him, you know he's insane. Of course the girls ask him for help, and after making sure they're alone, he drugs them so that he can keep them for his experiment.As the two girls awaken tied to their hospital beds, they're treated to one of the funniest overhead projector presentations ever: Doctor Heiter talks to his audience (the two girls, and prisoner #3 Katsuro (Akihiro Kitamura)) about how he's known as the top surgeon in regards to removing Siamese twins, and how he just wants more in life. He tells us about how he once created the legendary "3-dog" made from Rottweilers, and the process behind it, and then the slideshow begins. The entire surgical process (which apparently is "100% accurate") is discussed with hilarious drawings of how he's going to basically cut out everyone's knee caps so they can't stand, and how he's going to sew every one together from rear to mouth, to make a human centipede.Once the centipede is created, and all the awkwardness from having to watch one of the weirdest and most disturbing things you'll ever see is gone, the movie is actually pretty funny. Yes, that's right, this movie is entertaining, mostly in the fact that everything that happens after the centipede is created is completely ridiculous and nonsensical.Want to see the guy at the head of the centipede eat out of dog bowl while the Doctor eats breakfast? Check.Want to hear the Doctor scream at one of the girls in the rear segment to swallow poop? Check.It's extremely exploitative, but it's so over the top that it actually tones down the disgusting aspects of it.The main flaw and complaint I have about this movie isn't necessarily the story itself, but the flow of the story. The movie is basically three acts: The first fifteen minutes which are amazing and nerve wracking (because you're waiting to see the centipede), the middle forty five minutes which is the creation and "use" of the human centipede, and the last twenty to thirty minutes which could be thrown away. While the first two parts are at least entertaining and flow into each other, it all comes crashing to a halt in act three. It's actually really disappointing in regards to the whole film, because it really kills the mood that was building up until that point.The other flaw in the film that gets a little aggravating after a while is that it pretty much uses EVERY horror cliche that's out there. I realize we're in 2010 and a lot of things have already been done, but when most of the script seems like fill in the blanks for a horror movie, it's a little disappointing. The concept of the film is obviously completely out there and brand spanking new, but to have it presented in such a boring package is disheartening.While I do have such a huge complaint about the story (and progression), I don't want you to think this is a bad movie. It's actually quite entertaining for a film who's selling point is getting to see butts sewn to mouths. I give a lot of props to Dieter Laser because he actually seems legitimately crazy at some points, and he does an amazing job of portraying someone who's both emotionally void and out of his mind at the same time.One last interesting factoid is that the subtitle of this movie is (First Sequence), and after looking on IMDB, apparently there's a sequel coming out in 2011 with the subtitle of (Full Sequence). This both intrigues and scares me, only for the thought that maybe they'll attach more people next time. I mean, come on now, centipedes have "100 legs", and CGI nowadays is pretty realistic.And besides, when else are you going to see a non-adult film that completely revolves around going butt to mouth?

reviewText: I have two main points about THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE.One:If the director/writer (Tom Six) or should it be (Tom Sick) intended to create one of the most uncomfortable and disgust driven pieces of cinema in the history of mankind, he did it to the hilt.  This is one of the most horrific situations a person could find themselves in.  Death would be preferable.  The horror comes from the situation presented on screen.  The viewer is forced to experience the awful predicament of the victims as a demented madman gets his jollies from them.  The entire "first sequence" is torture porn, body mutilation, and of course has direct references to Coprophilia.  In short, had I known what the entire movie had involved I would not have seen it.  (This is just not my cup of tea.)  I admit that you can't get it out of your head for quite a while.  Some things you just can't "unsee."Two:The acting is mediocre until the horror starts.  Then the victims cry and plead in a believable fashion.  Before this, the two young ladies have a flat tire and no cell phone service in the middle of nowhere.  (How typical.)  Their acting is fairly terrible until they are captured.  A series of bad decisions and one failed opportunity doom them to their fate.  Dr. Heiter (Dieter Laser) is appropriately creepy and his acting is so over the top, I wonder why anyone would go in to his house let alone accept a glass of water from him.  He is depicted in a very "Nazi-like" manner.  The scenes had to be uncomfortable to film; I'll give the actors their due.  I think a gag (no pun intended) reel of bloopers would likely be hilarious.  The strongest actor in the film is the Japanese Businessman.  His rants and yells show some serious guts in his portrayal.  This movie is largely a waste of time full of disgusting and disturbing images.NOT FOR KIDS! (Or anyone else really)

reviewText: While story development may not be very extensive, Tom Six's The Human Centipede (First Sequence) (2010) does have an outlandish and original concept, that for better or worse, probably breaks some new ground in the horror genre, as a demented doctor performs some truly gruesome surgical procedures.  Be advised that some spoilers follow.American tourists Lindsay (Ashley C. Williams) and Jenny (Ashlynn Yennie), have car trouble while travelling in Germany.  Looking for help, they happen across the home of Dr. Heiter (Deiter Laser), a deranged physician who unfortunately has some rather sinister plans for them.  The girls are drugged, and are then tied down to hospital beds, located in a room in the basement.  A man is similarly bound to a third bed, but because he is "incompatible", Heiter euthanizes him.  The empty bed is soon filled by Katsuro (Akihiro Kitamura), an angry Japanese man, who expends his energy raving and cursing, as the doctor clinically describes the shocking procedure has planned for them, the formation of a three person "human centipede".While the actors credit for enduring what must have been a lot of discomfort, after such a dramatic build up, although quite grotesque, the human centipede is still something of a disappointment, as the construct is nearly helpless.  On their knees, joined together butt to mouth, the "first sequence" finds Katsuro in the lead position, with Lindsay in the middle, and Jenny at the rear.  As you imagine what they may be experiencing, you may have some empathy for their situation.  Having lost the use of their lower legs, even working together, this group can barely move.  There are several scenes of the "centipede" upstairs in the house, and even outside in the yard, although how the construct managed to get there from the basement is not shown.After the horrific transformation, not much that follows is really scary.  The "centipede" is more of a curiosity, where the gross out element is the passing of waste from one person to another.  Thankfully the matter of taking a pee never arises.  The women are topless, but down on all fours, you don't see very much.  Unable to speak, the women are usually moaning and crying.  Being at the front, Katsuro becomes the de facto leader, but since he speaks only Japanese, his ability to communicate is limited, as he continues to vent his anger and frustration.The sudden appearance of some police detectives investigating the disappearance of Heiter's victims, takes the film to a violent, though not very credible conclusion, as the centipede makes a rather laborious journey upstairs from the basement.  After a few impactful action sequences, this macabre experiment closes on a tragic note.Writer/director Tom Six's dark vision definitely scores some points for originality.  The film quickly establishes a creepy atmosphere, and raises expectations for something quite intense.  Unfortunately, the potential doesn't seem to be realized particularly well, and the story drags a bit after the transformation.  Although Dieter Laser's edgy performance does help to carry the movie, there isn't quite enough story to make the film a complete success.  The saga continues in Six'sHuman Centipede II: Full Sequence(2011), which features a 12 person centipede.
summary: atmospheric, and shocking, but this centipede moves quite slowly...

reviewText: Two American girls tour Europe. Staying in Germany, they decide to go out at night, travelling by car through the woods and... guess what? Something happens and they find themselves looking for survival in the very place they thought would shelter them, in their mad-scientist savior's home.In my view, this movie belongs to a strain of punchy European horror movies around the likes of Inside, Martyrs, Haute Tension: intelligent yet disturbing horror films that make US or Asian productions pale in comparison. Now, avid gore, SFX-seekers, hardcore horror fans looking for first-degree, violence-for-free stuff like Saw or Hostel might be disappointed as horror is more subtle here. Rather, the depicted horror leaves a lingering feeling of weirdness LONG after having watched the movie. It is neither the scenario (basic), nor the use of SFX (few and low-key), the theme (Frankenstein myth) or gore `n blood (virtually non-existent, as most of the violence is suggested). Horror comes from this illustration of Rabelais' centuries-old "science without conscience is the ruin of the soul".There's this brilliant, clinically precise scientist who's no longer capable of caring for human individuals... who quickly becomes the embodiment of the ultimate nightmare... the human monster with brains and no empathy whose mantra could be: "I-want-your-body-because-you-are-material-for-creation-now-try-to-understand-if-you-can". This monster prays on innocent people (foreigners who have nothing to be criticized for) for only one reason: they crossed his path to Creation and God... It's about surgery seen as arts, no matter the victims'suffering and humiliation. There is a subliminal reminiscence of past illustrations of this very type of horror : human experiments in WW2's Nazi and China-based Japanese prisoner camps... Plus, the main character is German, the action takes place in Germany and supporting characters are Japanese and Americans... Now, do you recall??The clinical edge of the movie is achieved mainly through cold lighting, settings and shooting as well as the deliberate disregard for any primary color. Materials and colors are dull, soul-less. The six main actors/actresses add credibility to the whole narrative. Dieter Laser, the German actor, is top notch in his portraying of a cold, unpredictable, unreachable, worldwide renown yet morally-dead scientist celebrity who admits "hating humans".This movie's worth watching but be warned, it requires tolerance towards moral horror. Otherwise you might just miss the whole film... or be outright scandalized by its intrinsic violence.

reviewText: I know a lot of people have slammed this movie for various reasons, and with good reason.  To put it bluntly this movie was not that great.  It’s plot was weak, some of the characters actions made no sense, and it seemed as if it was made just for pure shock value.  That said, even if there were glaring issues with the movie, the idea behind it was creative.  I mean, how do you come up with an idea like that?  For a low-budget movie it certainly made the rounds.  I think pretty much everyone has heard of this movie.  Not everyone has watched it—my kids included—but it generated a lot of buzz just based off its concept.  As for the movie itself, it was entertaining, gory, and even repulsive at times—but in a good way.  I didn’t love it, but I enjoyed it.  I thought the crazy doctor did a great job.  If you are a true fan of horror and haven’t seen this one yet, you definitely want to check it out.T.S. CharlesAuthor of young adult book, "Consumed." Available on Amazon.
